contextId.quote: your sons and your daughters ... will fall by the sword

Similar words appear in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:03:01|3:1]]. AT: "the Judah people group" or "the people of Judah" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

Here "the people of Ammon" refers to the land that belonged to the people of Ammon. Also the missing words at the beginning of this phrase may be added. AT: "I will make the rest of the land of Ammon a field for flocks" (See [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
contextId.quote: the people of Ammon a field for flocks

contextId.information: The word "you" refers to the people of Ammon but is also a metonym for their land and their possessions. AT: "I will allow enemies to defeat you and take you, your land, and your possessions as plunder" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: give you as plunder to the nations

contextId.information: There places refer to the people who live in them. AT: "the people of Moab and Seir" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

The word "house" is a metonym for the family that lives in the house, in this case the descendants of Judah over many years. Similar words appear in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:03:01|3:1]]. AT: "The Judah people group are" or "The people of Judah are" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "Edom" refers to the people who live there. AT: "The people of Edom" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

The word "house" is a metonym for the family that lives in the house, in this case the descendants of Judah over many years. Similar words appear in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:03:01|3:1]]. AT: "the Judah people group" or "the people of Judah" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

Here the "hand" of Israel is a metonym for Israel's army. Yahweh speaks of taking revenge on the people of Edom as if his vengeance were like a sheet that he covered them with. AT: "I will use my people Israel to take revenge against the people of Edom" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I will lay my vengeance upon Edom by the hand of my people Israel

contextId.information: Here Yahweh's power is represented by his "hand." AT: "I will turn my powerful hand against the Philistines" or "I will turn my great power against the Philistines" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: I will reach out with my hand against the Philistines

contextId.information: Here the city names "Tyre" and "Jerusalem" represent the people of those cities. AT: "the people of Tyre have said against the people of Jerusalem" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here to be "filled up" represents being prosperous. AT: "I will become prosperous" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

Here the word "nations" refers to their armies. AT: "I will gather armies from many nations that will beat against you like the waves in the raging sea" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: I will raise up many nations against you like the sea raises its waves

contextId.information: Part of Tyre was an island. This expression is a metonym for the results of Tyre's destruction. AT: "an empty island used for drying fishing nets" or "a deserted island where people dry out their fishing nets" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: a place for nets to dry out in the midst of the sea

contextId.information: "Plunder" means things that people steal or take by force. Here Tyre becoming plunder represents its wealth being carried off by other nations. AT: "the armies of the nations will take away every valuable thing from Tyre" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: she will become plunder for the nations

contextId.information: Possible meanings are 1) "Her daughters" were the young women of Tyre who were working in the fields or 2) "Her daughters" is a metonym for nearby towns and villages on the mainland that supported the main city of Tyre. AT: "Her daughter communities who are on the mainland" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Her daughters who are in the fields

contextId.information: Here the word "He" refers to Nebuchadnezzar and is a metonym for his army. AT: "His army will kill" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

Possible meanings are 1) "your daughters" refers to the young women of Tyre who were working in the fields or 2) "your daughters" is a metonym for nearby towns and villages on the mainland that supported the main city of Tyre. AT: "your daughter communities who are on the mainland." See how you translated a similar phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:26:05|26:6]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

The metonym 'in your hand" means "in your possession." This can be stated in active form. AT: "You owned goods" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Here "Aram" refers to the people of Aram. AT: "The people of Aram were dealers" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "Judah and the land of Israel" refers to the people of those places. AT: "The people of Judah and Israel were trading with you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Judah and the land of Israel were trading with you

contextId.information: This is a metonym for the people of Dan and Javan. AT: "The people of Dan and Javan" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This is a metonym for the people of Dedan. AT: "The people of Dedan were" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This is a metonym for the people of Arabia. AT: "The people of Arabia" or "The Arabians" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

This refers to the people from these places. AT: "The people of Haran, Canneh, and Eden were traders with you, along with the people of Sheba, Asshur, and Kilmad" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Haran, Canneh, and Eden were traders with you, along with Sheba, Asshur, and Kilmad

contextId.information: Here "Cities at the sea" represents the people in those cities. AT: "The people of the cities by the sea" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Cities at the sea will tremble

contextId.information: Here "heart" represents the will or thoughts of the ruler of Tyre. AT: "You are arrogant" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "heart" represents the mind or thinking. AT: "you think that you have the mind of a god" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: you make your heart like the heart of a god

contextId.information: Here "heart" refers to the will or thoughts of the ruler of Tyre. See how you translated the similar phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:28:01|28:2]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: you have made your heart like the heart of a god

contextId.information: Here "the pit" refers to the grave or to hell. AT: "down to the grave" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "sword" is a metonym for an attacking enemy army. AT: "When enemy armies attack you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: When the sword comes against you

contextId.information: The word "house" is a metonym for the family that lives in the house. In this case it refers to Israel's descendants. Translate this as in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:03:01|3:1]]. AT: "the Israelites" or "the Israelite people group" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "Jacob" represents the descendants of Jacob. AT: "the descendants of my servant Jacob" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

Here "sword" is a metonym for battle, and "bring a sword against you" is a metaphor for causing an enemy army to come fight against Egypt. AT: "I will cause your enemies to come fight against you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: I will bring a sword against you

contextId.information: Here "Egypt" represents the people of Egypt, and "scatter" represents causing them to move to other places. AT: "I will scatter the Egyptians among the nations" or "I will make the people of Egypt go and live among the nations" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I will scatter Egypt among the nations

contextId.information: Here "Egypt" is a metonym for the people of Egypt, and "gather" is a metaphor for causing them to return to Egypt.  AT: "I will cause the people of Egypt to return to Egypt" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Here "turn ... for help" is a metonym for "ask ... for help." AT: "whenever they asked Egypt to help them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: when they turned to Egypt for help

contextId.information: An animal horn represents the animal's strength, so horn is a metonym for strength. God speaks of making Israel strong as if Israel were an animal, and he were to cause its horn to grow. AT: "I will make the people of Israel strong" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I will make a horn sprout up for the house of Israel

contextId.information: The word "sword" here represents war or an army that attacks. AT: "There will be war against Egypt" or "An enemy army will attack Egypt" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Then a sword will come against Egypt

contextId.information: Here "fall" represents dying, and "the sword" represents battle. AT: "Egypt's soldiers will die in battle" or "an attacking army will kill Egypt's soldiers in battle" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: their soldiers will fall by the sword

contextId.information: Here "Pelusium" is a metonym for the people of the city near Pelusium, and "be in severe agony" can be translated with the verb "suffer." AT: "The people of Pelusium will suffer terribly" or "The people of Pelusium will feel terrible pain" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: Pelusium will be in severe agony

contextId.information: Here "face enemies" represents seeing or having enemies. AT: "Memphis will have enemies every day" or "Enemies will fight against Memphis every day" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Memphis will face enemies every day

contextId.information: The word "sword" is used here to refer to a battle or war. AT: "will die in battle" or "will die in the war" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

Here "cities" represents the people of the cities. The abstract noun "captivity" can be expressed with the more concrete noun "captive" or the verb "capture" AT: "the people of their cities will become captives" or "and their enemies will capture their people and take them away" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: their cities will go into captivity

contextId.information: Here "will fall" represents being weak. AT: "but Pharaoh will not be able to use his arms" or "Pharaoh's arms will be so weak that he cannot use them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

This refers to the grave; because the grave was thought to be the entrance to the world of the dead, the pit also represents that world. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:26:19|26:20]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

Here "swords" represents enemies who fought them in battle. This can be stated in active form. AT: "whom enemies had killed with swords" or "who had died in battle" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: who had been killed by the sword

contextId.information: Here "heart" represents the people's emotions. AT: "I will make the hearts of many peoples afraid" or "I will cause many people to be terrified" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: I will terrify the heart of many peoples

contextId.information: Here "sword" represents an army. AT: "The army of the king of Babylon will attack you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: The sword of the king of Babylon will come against you

contextId.information: "The pit" refers to the grave; because the grave was thought to be the entrance to the world of the dead, the pit also represents that world. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:31:16|31:16]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This represents the beginning of war. AT: "War has begun" [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This represents defeat in battle. AT: "Egypt has been handed over to be defeated in battle" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "Elam" refers to the people of that country. AT: "The people of Elam are also there in Sheol" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "the sword" represents warfare. AT: "in battle" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

The pit" refers to the grave; because the grave was thought to be the entrance to the world of the dead, the pit also represents that world. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:32:22|32:23]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "the sword" represents warfare. AT: "killed in battle" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This represents "those who were killed." See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:32:24|32:25]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "Edom" represents all the people of Edom. AT: "the people of Edom are in Sheol with their kings and all their leaders." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Edom is there with her kings and all her leaders

contextId.information: "The pit" refers to the grave; because the grave was thought to be the entrance to the world of the dead, the pit also represents that world. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:32:24|32:25]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
The word "sword" refers to an enemy army that attacks. Also, "land" refers to the people who live there. AT: "an army to attack the people of any land" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "sword" represent to an enemy army. AT: "He looks for an enemy army" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

Here "blood" represents death. The phrase "on his own head" is an idiom that means the person will be held responsible. AT: "it is their own fault if they die" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: each one's blood is on his own head

contextId.information: The word "sword" refers to an enemy army. AT: "the enemy army as it is coming" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the sword as it is coming

contextId.information: Here "sword" represents an enemy army. AT: "the enemy army comes and kills anyone" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the sword comes and takes anyone's life

contextId.information: Here "blood" represents a person's death. The phrase "I will require his blood from" is an idiom that means to consider someone responsible. AT: "I will consider that person's death to be the fault of the watchman" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: I will require his blood from the watchman

contextId.information: Here "house" represents people. AT: "the people of Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "mouth" represents what Yahweh says. AT: "you will hear the message that I speak and you will warn them on my behalf" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: you will hear the words from my mouth and warn them on my behalf

contextId.information: Here "blood" represents a person's death. The phrase "require ... from your hand" is an idiom that means to consider someone responsible. AT: "I will consider you responsible for his death" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: I will require his blood from your hand

contextId.information: Here "house" represents people. AT: "people of Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

The word "hand" is often used to refer to someone's power or action. A person with his hand on another person has power over that other person. See how you translated a similar phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:01:01|1:3]]. AT: "Yahweh was controlling me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: The hand of Yahweh had been on me

contextId.information: Here "blood" represents a person's life. To pour out blood is an idiom that means to murder. AT: "you murder people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Here "swords" represent doing violent things. AT: "You have committed violent acts with your swords to get what you want" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: You have depended on your swords

contextId.information: Here "you" refers to Ezekiel, and here he represents the message he speaks. This compares Ezekiel's message to a lovely song, which means the people enjoy listening to him, but they do not think his message is important enough to obey. AT: "they think that your words are like a lovely song" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: you are like a lovely song to them

contextId.information: Here "mouths" represent eating. AT: "so they will not be able to eat them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "hand" represents power or control. AT: "from the control of those who made them slaves" or "from those who made them slaves" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: from the hand of those who enslaved them

contextId.information: Here "nations" represents the people of the nations. AT: "The people of the nations will no longer steal from them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: They will no longer be plunder for the nations

contextId.information: Here "nations" represents the people of the nations. The abstract noun "insults" can be stated as a verb. AT: "the people of the nations will no longer insult them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: the nations will not bring insults against them

contextId.information: Here "hand" represents power. AT: "I will use my power to strike you" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: I will strike you with my hand

contextId.information: Here "bloodshed" represents being wounded or killed. AT: "I will allow your enemies to brutally kill many of you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: I will prepare you for bloodshed

contextId.information: Here "bloodshed" represents being wounded or killed. AT: "Since you did hate it when enemies brutally killed the people of Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Since you did not hate bloodshed

contextId.information: Here "heart" and "spirit" represent a person's inner being. The UDB reverses the order of these phrases. AT: "insulted my people and joyfully took my land" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: had both joy in their heart and disdain in their spirit, as they seized my land

contextId.information: Here "house" represents people. AT: "the people of Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"I cared about my holy name." Here "name" represents Yahweh and his reputation. AT: "I wanted people to know that I am holy" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: I had compassion for my holy name

contextId.information: Here "house" represents people. AT: "the people of Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "name" represents Yahweh and his reputation. AT: "so that people will know that I am holy" or "so that people will honor me as holy" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "house" represents people. AT: "people of Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
The eyes represent sight. AT: "to those who pass by and see it" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: before the eyes of all who pass by

contextId.information: Here "house" represents people. This can be stated in active form. AT: "The people of Israel will ask me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: I will be asked by the house of Israel

contextId.information: The word "hand" is often used to refer to someone's power or action. A person with his hand on another person has power over that other person. See how you translated a similar phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:01:01|1:3]]. AT: "Yahweh was controlling me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: The hand of Yahweh was upon me

contextId.information: The word "house" is a metonym for the family that lives in the house, in this case the Israelites, the descendants of Jacob over many years. Translate this as in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:03:01|3:1]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
The tribe of Judah lived in the southern kingdom of Israel which was called Judah. Here the name is used to refer to the whole southern kingdom. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

Joseph was Ephraim's father. The tribe of Ephraim lived in the northern kingdom of Israel. Here the names are used to represent to the whole northern kingdom. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: For Joseph, the branch of Ephraim

contextId.information: "the stick of Joseph." This represents the kingdom of Israel. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
The word "hand" refers to power. AT: "that is in the power of Ephraim" or "that the tribe of Ephraim rules over" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: that is in the hand of Ephraim

contextId.information: "the stick of Judah." This represents the kingdom of Judah. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

Yahweh said "David" to refer to a descendant of David. See how you translated "my servant David" in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:34:22|34:23]]. AT: "A descendant of my servant David"(See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here the "sword" represents war. AT: "recovered from war" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "hand" refers to the fact that these prophets wrote down Yahweh's message. AT: "my means of my servants" or "through my servants" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: by the hand of my servants

contextId.information: Here "sword" refers to a military attack. AT: "I will cause fighting to happen in his midst" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: I will summon a sword against him

contextId.information: Here "sword" represents battle. AT: "all of his soldiers will fight each other" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: each man's sword will be against his brother

contextId.information: Here "blood" refers to injury and death when blood is shed. AT: "by causing them to be sick and to be wounded or killed in battle" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

Here "my holy name" refers to Yahweh's character. This can be stated in active form. AT: "I will make my people, Israel, know that I am holy" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: I will make my holy name known in the midst of my people Israel

contextId.information: The word "house" is a metonym for the family that lives in the house, in this case the Israelites, the descendants of Jacob over many years. Translate this as in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:03:01|3:1]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here the word "hand" refers to Yahweh's power that he exercises to bring punishment. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

The word "house" is a metonym for the family that lives in the house, in this case the Israelites, the descendants of Jacob over many years. Translate this as in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:03:01|3:1]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

The word "house" is a metonym for the family that lives in the house, in this case the Israelites, the descendants of Jacob over many years. Translate this as in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:03:01|3:1]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "sword" represents death in battle. Translate this as in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:32:22|32:23]]. AT: "were killed in battle" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

The word "house" is a metonym for the family that lives in the house, in this case the Israelites, the descendants of Jacob over many years. Translate this as in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:03:01|3:1]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

Here "sight" is a metonym for "seeing" and "seeing" is a metonym for understanding. AT: "many nations will understand that I am holy because of what did for the house of Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: I will show myself to be holy in the sight of many nations
